In this case glean what is spiritually functional by taking the child of what is true and good out of the bathtub of your investigation. With Love and nurturing care dry the child off.  And then, throw out that dirty bath water. <br />
B00001NFCY|5.0|The 1990s saw the rise of Alternative Rock.  Alternative Rock was originally a term that was a \\"catch all\\" to describe those genres of music that didn't fit into the mainstream. In the 80s, you had Punk, New Wave, College Rock, Underground music, etc. All of these were considered Alternative Rock. One genre that evolved as an offshoot was Grunge. Nirvana really lead the movement here. I looked at Grunge as integrating elements of heavy guitar (to a minor extent acoustic elements), heavy drumming, and often a feeling of anger and frustration.  As Nirvana led this revolution in the industry, they helped bring not just Grunge - but the entire Alternative Rock movement into the mainstream.   Eventually Grunge would begin to move toward the background and an off-shoot called Post Grunge would take place.  The elements of Post Grunge music contain simple chord progressions and gentle verses followed by louder choruses.      For whatever reason, Post Grunge sounds now seems to be the dominant form of music.   Many longtime popular music fans have accused this type of music of being very \\"cookie cutter\\" and all sounding the same.   I feel there is validity in that statement.   In the midst of this transition from Grunge to Post Grunge was a band from Florida named Creed.  Creed's debut album, \\"My Own Prison\\" would add a third element - a Christian influence in their music.  This album would demonstrate how Creed rode a fine line between Grunge and Post Grunge as well as lay the foundations for a successful career.  \\"My Own Prison\\" was a good album, but contained a very \\"raw\\" sound.  It would be Creed's follow-up album, \\"Human Clay\\" that would polish-up this raw sound.   While I wouldn't call this one of the all-time albums, it still is strong enough to be considered the best album for 2000. <br /> <br />\\"Human Clay\\" was actually released in 1999, but it was an album that would have an impact all throughout the year 2000 and beyond.    While this is a very good album, it still falls short of being rated an all-time great album.  Overall, I consider 2000 to be a down year in the music industry.  For the year 2000, this album would emerge as the best of the lot. <br /> <br />As for the album, for all practical purposes - the Christian influence is not really all that present on this album.  This album shows some darker tones and integrates many of the Grunge roots of faith and despair.   Song titles such as \\"Wrong Way\\" and \\"Faceless Man\\" exemplify this darker tones.  Creed does a good job at putting a \\"loose fitting segue\\" between these two songs - allowing one to flow into another.   At the same time, there are still some uplifting songs such as \\"Higher\\" and \\"Inside Us All\\" <br /> <br />As mentioned above, I categorized \\"My Own Prison\\" as a Grunge album as opposed to a Post Grunge album.   This was a hard rocking album with a heavy electric guitar sound and songs of personal anguish.  I felt the sound of \\"My Own Prison\\" was too hard to put into the Post Grunge category.   One problem with \\"My Own Prison\\" was a raw sound.   The guitars of Mark Tremonti - as good as they are - contributed to this raw sound.   One of the problems I had was that lead vocalist Scott Stapp was often overpowered by Tremonti's guitars.  This was not a unique problem to Creed - as many other bands have had the same problem (Van Halen had this problem at times when Eddie Van Halen's guitar would overpower both Sammy Hagar and David Lee Roth's vocals).   The good news is that on \\"Human Clay\\", this isn't as much a problem.   On \\"Human Clay\\", things are \\"toned down\\" a bit.   The nice thing is that Creed doesn't lose their hard rock sound.  At the same time, we hear Stapp's amazing vocals emerge on this album - proving that Stapp is one of the great vocalists in the music industry.   This \\"toning down\\" puts this album closer into the Post Grunge mold of simple chord progressions and louder choruses. <br /> <br />If you heard the two major hits on this album, \\"With Arms Wide Open\\" and \\"Higher\\", you really hear how good Stapp is.   These songs are sometimes criticized, but really the only downside I can think of is that they were overplayed on the radio.     Stapp delivers more than vocals on this song, but a full-blown performance in this song that is a message to his newborn child.   This song also exemplifies how Creed \\"tones it down\\" and gets an optimum balance between his vocals and Tremonti's guitar.       <br /> <br />But this album will has more than the hits.   Songs such as \\"Are You Ready\\", \\"What If\\", \\"Say I\\", \\"Wrong Way\\", \\"Faceless Man\\", \\"Never Die\\", and \\"Inside Us All\\" are all very good songs.  These songs definitely will require several listens, but as you listen to them - you will get an appreciation.    \\"Are You Ready\\" and \\"What If\\" are cut more from the Grunge mold of \\"My Own Prison\\".  Both songs also continue to showcase the balance of Stapp's vocals and Tremonti's guitar work.   \\"Never Die\\" is another one of those songs I just didn't care for at first, but the more I listened to it, the more I liked it.    From a musical standpoint, you will hear the raw sound of Creed in the chorus and the more polished sound on the main verses.   \\"Inside Us All\\" shows what great songwriters Creed were.   The song says \\"There's a peace inside us all\\" - creating an uplifting end to an album that does have some darker overtones.     <br /> <br />The liner notes include all of the lyrics which is good considering that Creed writes some great lyrics.   Perhaps the only weak point is that Creed might have lost some of their identity by moving away from the Christian influence that permeated \\"My Own Prison\\".    This is still a very good album - one that I'd recommend.

B00004S5TK|3.0|Led Zeppelin fans are deeply devided in their feelings for the band's 1976 concert film \\"The Song Remains The Same\\". They either love it or they think it's outright horrible. I think they are the greatest rock and roll band ever. I have never heard a band with more soul, talent, emotion and presence than these four guys.<br /><br />\\"The Song Remains The Same\\" is a compilation of select performances from the group's legendary 1973 concert at the world renowned New York venue Madison Square Garden. However, we don't even get to see the whole show.<br /><br />The movie opens with some weird (and bloody) gangster movie fantasy sequence, then goes throgh about 15 minutes of the band at home with their family and getting ready for the show.<br /><br />The concert opens with a flacid and uninspired performance of \\"Rock & Roll\\".  The band is playing with the least of their abilities, andPlant's voice sound shot. Next is a more lively version of \\"Black Dog\\", followed by a raw and powerful \\"Since I've Been Loving You\\". Next comes \\"No Quarter\\", which, while a great performance, features a horridly cheesy fantasy sequence, the first of many.<br /><br />After a few minutes of backstage footage, we get \\"The Song Remains The Same\\", which is a solid performance. Next comes \\"The Rain Song\\", which, while performed beautifully, is accompanied by yet another cheesy fantasy.<br /><br />After some more backstage footage, we get to the film's low point. \\"Dazed And Confused\\" was known to drag on for a good 25 minutes (sometimes more), but this version is exceptionally boring and the fantasy sequence is horridly uninteresting.<br /><br />The rest of the movie is pretty solid. The performances are all full of life and overall great, especially \\"Stairway To Heaven\\", which manages to go completely uninterrupted throughout its length. The movie wraps up with a powerful \\"Whole Lotta Love\\".<br /><br />Overall, not a bad effort, but this is not the best of Zeppelin live. Thankfullt in 2003, Jimmy Page compikled a new two disc dvd featuring concrts by the band spanning nine years, including lost footage from the movie. It is much better than this, though I would recommend buying both since this film while flawed is quite intersting and overall enjoyable.s up with a powerful \\"Whole Lotta Love\\". In fact, I would even add one more powerful word preceding the phrase as follows: 'See, Think & Act Differently.'<br /><br />Let me share this harsh reality: You can't do things differently until you see things differently.<br /><br />Anthony Robbins puts it very beautifully (at the Mastery University): \\"The difference between those who succeed & those who fail isn't what they have. It's what they choose to see & do with their resources & experiences of life.\\"<br /><br />This means all of us have a choice in life. So, exercise your power of choice. This is the vital key to wealth & abundance.<br /><br />To sum up my review, I must say, reading this book has been a refreshing exercise for me in spite of the slick factor & hyperbolic stuff. B0000028UK|5.0|As the years have passed, my tastes in music have changed, and as a result, PJ started to see less and less time in my stereo, finally falling completely off my radar screen as bands like Radiohead and other electronic-based rock really started to move music in a different direction. <br /> <br />Recently I just got offered tickets to the PJ show coming up touring their new disc, so I spent a long drive listening to all their discs.  I completely forgot how great this disc is.  There is not a bad track on this album, and it really exemplifies the grunge movement of the times.  The sound is distinctly Pearl Jam's, not some other band's, with Vedder agonizing over each syllable he sings and the music constantly moving with a purpose - there is an incredible sense of importance to the music.  Often PJ has been criticized for being over the top with their sense of importance, however, in this edition, the music with its unique sound easily carries the weight and gives you a sense rock really is not dead at all.   <br /> <br />It's hard to rate this disc in terms of where it stands with other PJ discs, simply due to the fact I think each of their albums has a different tone - let's just say this is less rock than Ten, but more refined than Vitalogy and a whole hell of a lot better than the self-titled one that just came out (although I've only listened to it once, first impression wasn't great) <br /> <br />Bottom line, if you're a new PJ fan, please go back and buy this album <br /> <br /> <br />

0446310786|5.0|Harper Lee makes an excellent debut with \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\", a story that examines racial issues and other issues through the eyes of an 8-year-old tomboy named Scout Finch. Scout lives in the small town of Maycomb in Alabama. The novel examines her life and how she responds to large-scale issues and small, petty problems in her own life. This novel is more of a slice of life, with the main narrative problem and solution not coming until the end. <br /> <br />Scout Finch is 8 years old when the story begins. She spends most of her time acting out stories with her brother Jem and their beloved friend Dill. The trio also has a fascination with Boo Radley, a man who has evolved into an urban legend. The three make it their goal to make him leave his house. The book focuses on Scout's small worldview for the first half or so, how all she cares about is making Boo Radley come out and acting out plays in the summer. That all changes when her father, Atticus, decides to defend a young black man accused of rape. As racial issues and prejudices broaden Scout's view of things, we can only go along for the ride. <br /> <br />This is a true masterpiece, with excellent characters like Atticus and Dill, along with the youthful innocence of Scout. \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\" is a classic, a read that truly depicts life in a way I had never experienced before.
B000EMGAOY|5.0|The truth about this album is that it's extremely deep.  In fact, I'd say besides being this band's deepest album I'd say it's the deepest album I can think of right now off the top of my head.  By deep, I mean there are 28 songs, mostly all of which are very strong tracks, and standout tracks in their own respective ways.  I'll try to say something insightful about each track... <br /> <br />Note that I think theres a lot more going on on the second Disc (Mars).  I would describe the first disc as good and the second as nearly mind-blowing, and extremely solid.  <br /> <br />Dani California:  The Mary Jane's Last Dance parallel is uncanny.   When I first heard this song on the radio before the album dropped I remember turning to a friend in the car and saying this sounds a lot like Mary Jane's Last Dance.  Not sure what the deal is here.  I'd say that Frusciante probably heard the Tom Petty song shortly before coming up with the riff and that it was the work of the unconcsious, IF the lyrics and drum beat werent so similar too.  Not sure what else to say about this one.  Its a simple almost folky song with a simple drum beat that sets its tone.  I like the section in the middle where anthony and John sing in unison in real high pitch. <br /> <br />Snow:  This might be the catchiest song on the album and it definately was one of the first and easiest songs to grab me.  Now it sounds to me like one of the poppiest songs on the album.     Sounds to me like it could have easily fit into By The Way. <br /> <br />Charlie:  Strong song, not one of my faves, but I could see this one growing on me over the course of years. <br /> <br />Stadium Arcadium:  Very nice, one of the darker songs on the album, sung in a sad tone.  One of the cooler guitar solos on the album.  They use a cool, echoey, almost western-like effect for it.  Everytime I hear it I picture a western saloon for some reason (think Desperado) To me theres nothing super cool about this strack other than that solo. <br /> <br />Hump De Bump:  Fun song, don't listen to this one often, nothing i absolutely love about it right now. <br /> <br />She's Only 18:  This one's the standout of the first disc for me.  One of the best songs on the album.  Arguably the best chorus on the album.  So heavy, a little slow but urgent.  This guitar solo works the best of any track because the segue into the last chorus is seemless and amazing.  Amazing transition there, listen for it, it makes the whole song.  Also love Keidis' playful bird-sounding \\"haha\\" in the middle of the solo.   <br /> <br />Slow Cheetah:  Acoustic ballad, not crazy about the chorus, kind of sounds cheesy to me.  I wish they would have done soemthing more with it.  <br /> <br />Torure Me:  Fast drum beat, decent song, nothing really stands out for me to make me love it. <br /> <br />Strip My Mind:  One of the slowest paced songs on the album.  Nice chorus.  The song works.  What cool is this is a track where the whole band sings in unison for parts of it.  Kinda cool, theres a couple like that i think. Cant imagine hearing this live though. <br /> <br />Especially In Michigan:  I've heard people say that this album's lyrics are pointless and meaningless.  I completely disagree with this and love the poetry thru the whole thing but this song is probably a testamate for those reviews.  Other than making a reference to the Detroit Lions and Tigers (kinda cool), the lyrics dont mean much...but they work, and to me they are just random observations about the state where Kiedis and Chad Smith grew up.  As far as the song goes, to me this is another stand out of the disc.  I love the chorus here.  Its very interesting, distorted and sounds like there might be 2 or 3 voices chanting the distortion, but it might also just be frusciante.  Who knows.  Very cool. <br /> <br />Warlocks:  I dont care much for this one.  Theres just not enough going on with it.  One thing thats cool though is theres a verse in the middle that stands out because it sounds so different (\\"Make a deal with...\\")  Its very cool and sounds to me like something off of Dark Side of the Moon.   <br /> <br />C'Mon Girl:  Arghhhh.  This songs not bad at all, nice guitar riff and a cool baseline, BUT the chorus absolutely bludgeons this one for me.  It just doesnt fit the song, and I'd say it even ruins it for me, making the song almost intolerable.  Wish they would have done something with the Chorus. <br /> <br />Wet Sand:  Heres a song that really evolves and has an energy that slowly builds throughout the whole song.  This is an example of one of many very creative tracks on this album that shows lots of versatility by containing sections that sound somewhat different, or extrapalate on eachother.  The Chorus is amazing.    Theres a point about 2/3 the way through the song right when the second chorus kicks in that is the absolute climax of this song.  Theres a swooshy, space-like sound effect and then the chorus kicks in, but unlike the first chorus, this one has another sound effect thats really cool and continues throughout the entire chorus, underlying everything and changing tone all along.  Its very discreet and you have to listen for it.  Not sure why I love this so much but, just adds energy I think.   Probably something Rubin threw in to add character.  Nice ending too. <br /> <br />Hey:  Not much to say about this one.  Kind of a lame chorus.  Good placement of this song because its successor is one of the stars of the album... <br /> <br />Desecration Smile:  Ohhhh yea, this song is a total emotional rollercoaster.  Its a somber, its joyous, its reflective.  All around just an extemely versatile and well composed piece. It starts out sounding like it's going to be a fluid ballad but about 20 seconds in it takes a drastic turn and the mood is set.  Kiedis vocals here are like nothing we've heard from him before (sung in such high pitch)  He sounds a lot like Neil Young from CSNY times.  Keidis' volcals hereare a major and crucial component of this song, but I'd say everything else is as important.  Everyone comes to play here.  Nice picking guitar work by fruciante. <br /> <br />Tell Me Baby:  Another gem on the album.  Totally cool track.  Lots of personality, great representation of this band.  Cool theme about the motives of 20-somethings that move out to LA searching for something they cant even put their finger on.   Nice rapping section in the middle.  Very versatile track, very nice chorus.  Overall extremely solid and I hope this DOES NOT become a single because I would hate for this to be overplayed and I generally steer away from songs designated for radio play (maybe for no reason at all, but I do) <br /> <br />Hard to Concentrate:  I think a lot of people really like this one, and personally I dont get it at all.  Probably one  of the 4 or 5 tracks I might dump if I were forced to cut the album down some.  Nice poem,  too schmoozy though. <br /> <br />21st Century:  An absolute standout for me.  Keidis' vocals dominate the whole song, and Fruciante brings the A-game.  Very dancable song with lots of energy.  Amazing chorus, amazing basework, Chad is solid on the drums, nice guitar solo closing it out.   <br /> <br />She Looks to Me:  Another stand out track for me.  This just works, dont know why i like it, kind of reminds me of early 90's rock.  Contains maybe my favorite verse on the album (\\"down in the south seas...\\")  So different than the rest of the track.  Cool lyrics here too.   I mean really, how much better can the album get from here???  LOTS... <br /> <br />Readymade:   Ohhhhhh man, I mean they keep bringing it track after track on this disc.  One of a handful of total gems on the album.  Hard rocking song from the start, a serious rocker, love the backround \\"ahhhhhh\\" vocals from the rest of the band behind Keidis' voice in the chorus. <br /> <br />If:  sounds like a slower phish song to me.  kind of a reflective song.  Cool electric sound effect underlying the entire song.  I'd consider this the breather of the second disc.  Some might say its a refreshing brake from the insanity and strength of the songs preceding and before they close the album out with another bundle of solid brilliance, others might consider this a break in the momentum. <br /> <br />Make You Feel Better:  Cool song about, well... I'll leave that one up to you.  Love Keidis' periodic \\"oh yea\\" high-pitch scream here.  If he didnt scream it I probably would.   <br /> <br />Animal Bar:  One of the most complex songs on the album.  It does different things.  It moves, it changes.  Grew on me the most.  Love the chorus (\\"rain on my...\\") and the \\"babadaba\\" in the background.  Crazy twist at the end and fizzles out... <br /> <br />So Much I:   how solid can this disc possibly be???  They are still bringing it with variance and full force here.  Like about 20 other songs on the album, this one has its own unique charater and sound thats nothing like the others.  Srong track. <br /> <br />Storm in a Teacup:  One of the gems, love the verse building up to both choruses \\"little lady love youre gonna make some\\"  brilliant structure of words and just well written.  This is almost beastie-boys meets RHCP.  You can hear the Rubin element here.  Energetic all the way through, but certain parts ooze enery, particularly when  it gets real quiet before the last chorus section and to me this sounds a lot like something off Check Your Head (an album i think rubin produced; not sure of this though)  Its got an extraordinary quality to it, great song.    <br /> <br />We Beleive:  Not sure what he deal is with this one, its definately the message of the album though.  I think its the band speaking directly to the album, almost a refleection from them.  I could be dead wrong.  Nice santana-ish guitar effect.  Cool lyrics.  \\"The risk is, it worth it, The disc is, it perfect?\\"  I'll let you answer that one.  Very cool distortion over Keidis' words to fade thetrack out.  <br /> <br />Turn it Again:  Huge rocker, very loud, led by somewhat distorted  heavy electric guitar.  This one is reminiscent of GunsnRoses for me, particularly toward the end.  Very heavy, very distrorted, similar sound. <br /> <br />Death of a Martian: Def a gem of the album, perfect closer, like nothing theyve ever done before.  Kind of trippy sound.  The song kind of trickles downward the whole time.  Some of the best lyrics on the album.  Very cool ending poem with some of the coolest lyrics I've ever heard in song.  Keidis ends the album on  a somewhat screaming \\"AWAAAAAAAAY\\" love it.  Great song to listen to while you reflect on what you just heard and its sad only because the album has come to an end.  Oh well, time to Turn it Again... <br /> <br /> <br />In closing I'd say there is definitely enough here to keep someone busy for a while and this is a truly expansive album.   <br /> <br />Thanks.
B00005JOVN|3.0|WARNING: SPOILERS!!<br /><br />Yes, I'm a fan of the original Irwin Allen film.<br />Yes, I have been on a couple of cruises.<br />Yes, I have seen James Cameron's \\"Titanic\\".<br />Yes, I can hum \\"The Morning After.\\"<br /><br />With those facts behind me, I can now embark on my take on Wolfgang Peterson's retelling of the '72 disaster classic.<br /><br />Shortening the original by almost an hour, Peterson's version delves sparingly into the lives of the stars and \\"dives\\" headfirst into the \\"adventure\\" for survival.  Perhaps, by having two familiar faces, Kurt Russell and Richard Dreyfuss, the director wants the audience to fill in the blanks about their respective characters.  Russell's is possibly an extension of the character that he played in \\"Backdraft\\" inasmuch as in this film he's a former New York firefighter turned mayor; Dreyfus is, perhaps, \\"Matt Hooper\\" from \\"Jaws,\\" after the great white scared him out of the closet.  Both actors didn't seem to stretch their acting muscles much in this film.<br /><br />As far as the rest of the cast is concerned, Josh Lucas's \\"reformation\\" from professional gambler to savior of the group is almost believable, considering the predicament in which the survivors find themselves.  Though he has more lines than original \\"captain\\" Leslie Neilson, Andre Braugher doesn't get too much screen time and \\"goes down with the ship,\\"...literally.<br /><br />Because of the brevity of character development, the rest of the cast is filled out with your basic stereotypes: the single mom and son (Jacinda Barrett and Jimmy Bennett), the young couple (Emmy Rossum and Mike Vogel), the stowaway (Mia Maestro), the wise-ass (Kevin Dillon), and the noble crewman (Freddy Rodriquez).<br /><br />The special effects are indeed spectacular but more than thirty years have passed since the first film and it's logical that there would be an improvement in that area.  However, the first one benefited from having characters of whom the audience could connect.  By going \\"straight for the jugular\\" with the massive effort spent on CGI effects and stuntwork, Peterson has crafted a nice-looking package but with nothing inside.<br /><br />And even the original had a nifty John Williams' score; Klaus Bedelt's does not compare, even to his own superlative score to the hit \\"Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl.\\"<br /><br />The film does have one great bonus: the sinking of the ship at the film's end.  That is a most likely occurence, considering the massive damage inflicted on the ship by the \\"rogue wave.\\"t spent on CGI effects and stuntwork, Peterson has crafted a nice-looking package but with nothing inside. B000EMGAOY|5.0|First of all, I think it's brave, if not bold, to launch your \\"comeback\\" with a double album. Most artists after a four year hiatus would have played it safe, but the fact that the Chili Peppers took a risk deserves special attention. \\"Stadium Arcadium\\" certainly qualifies as a collector's item because most double or single albums won't even approach this level of good. This is the kind of project that a great band should be capable of making this late into their career and the Red Hot Chili Peppers don't disappoint. From the moment you hear the first song \\"Dani California,\\" you're hooked. It reminds you of what has made this band so popular throughout the years.  And that's just the beginning.  Surprisingly, the album just keeps getting better. Most double albums would have collapsed halfway through the first set, but not this one. It's almost hard to appreciate both CD's just merely playing your favorites. When playing both disks straight through, that's when the greatness really hits you. \\"Stadium Arcadium\\" is almost overwhelming, but in a good way. It's hard to absorb it all. But that's a compliment. There's just so much good material. I wouldn't consider any song filler. I definitely think this is a big improvement over \\"By the Way.\\" The Red Hot Chili Peppers have clearly evolved and for the better. It's almost hard for me to properly describe \\"Stadium Arcadium,\\" I just think you have to experience it for any of this to be meaningful. This work is probably destined to become a future classic and with good reason. No one should be able to make a small masterpiece look this easy.
0780622553|2.0|The movie has great sets, and is kind of a mix between matrix and blade runner. However the acting is unconvincing, the big secret is revealed at the beginning, and the character development is weak.
B000068UXF|4.0|Before the DVD, I listened to Solti's CD. I liked it very much at first, and the more I listened to it, the more I loved it. I followed the libretto and I imagined a very fantastic kind of opera with lots of sets and coulours. <br /> <br />I thought that Studer made a very good Empress, better than Varady. I turn on the DVD instead of the CD when I want to listen to the Empress in particular. Her acting is not very good, however. Most of the time she has a confused open-mouthed expression, as if she had no idea why she was on stage. One thing to note is that she cut out most of the spoken text in the third act, not that it's important but it's strange to see a bad actor conveying internal conflict without words. When Empress gets her shadow, a very bright beam shines through her skirt and you can't help noticing what huge legs she has. <br /> <br />I'll agree with other reviewers on Lipovsek. I was surprised by her excellent acting, she exhibited a whole range of emotions. She would stoop at times, and even swagger too. The only problem is in Act III, when she's misdirecting Barak and Wife. She moves her head around a lot and it seems like the mic doesn't catch everything clearly. Although she isn't as constant and Runkel, I really did enjoy her interpretation. <br /> <br />I don't like Marton's voice. It seems devoid of any delicacy. Here too, she screams most of her lines. They're accompanied with a ton of facial contortions. To make matters worse, the high notes don't even come out right. You can barely tell them apart because her vibrato is so wobbly. It's most notable at the end of the quartet in Act III, where she and Studer don't even sing the same note. Her acting is fun to watch though. For example, her reaction to the screaming fish is hilarious. She even starts crying at Act III. At least Behrens had the prerequisite vocal range, though I never really know what to think of her interpretations because her voice and singing seem so unusual. <br /> <br />Hale looks frail, but his singing is satisfactory. He's thin so you can see the bulging veins on his neck... a bit distracting. His acting was fine too, except he doesn't look very menacing when he's treatening the Wife. During Act III, he's stuck on the right side of the stage, sulking adorably. <br /> <br />Moser has the best costume! His singing is really light compared to Domingo. During the quartets and duets, it's especially noticeable. The huge bags under his eyes and his facial contortions give him an ever-changing mask. It's awkward and distracting. I don't think the role of the Emperor requires a lot of acting anyway. <br /> <br />Terfel as one of the messengers is very good. He's floating in a corner at the begining, which is really not how I pictured the scene. His make up doesn't make sense to me either. Another weird one is the female messenger; she looks absurd. The falcon is just a mass of red flesh that doesn't move at all. The chorus is really excellent though. <br /> <br />The staging was the most disappointing part. The stage is vast yet the sets are painfully diminutive. The scene where Nurse first tempts Barak's Wife with the crown is the only one that's impressive. The last act was the worst. There's no scene change during the Empress and Emperor's descent; instead they just hang out on stage, smiling and moving about aimlessly. Then, when I saw Studer \\"pull out\\" Marton's shadow from a roll on the ground, I was simiply shocked. And then no golden bridge materialized, Barak and Barak's wife just walk on her \\"shadow\\". That was absolutely ridiculous, what self-respecting singer would agree to move the set, during a performance, and in front of the audience? What they did to create the golden spring was so pathetic: two plastic cylinder filled with water and air bubbles coming up. Also the spirit messenger here looks like a singing rectangle. Why??? Barak's sword turned out to be a cheap looking lightsabre wannabe. The lighting wasn't good either. You can barely see Marton's face during the end of Act II. Also when Barak and his Wife are looking for each other, there's an awkward \\"searchlight\\" effect going on. The last scene with the chorus of unborn children is also very weird. I don't know who they paid to the background, but it looks so dumb! There's raw wooden paneling on the extremities and it looks out of place when the performers are there. I didn't like how they handled the broom bit. The \\"handsome\\" fellow Wife met on a bridge is terrifying. He looks very bright and metallic. The special effects for the Nurse's magic tricks aren't spectacular. It's hard to see the fish flying and the bed breaking happens in the dark. <br /> <br />So in the end, this is a good DVD. The singing and conducting is worthwhile, even if the visual aspect doesn't contribute much.

B000002UAX|5.0|The Beatles are the greatest band ever.They are great,terrific,excellent and superb.Each and every song on this album is a classic.Get this with Abbey road.Highly recommended.
B000EMGAOY|5.0|The truth about this album is that it's extremely deep. In fact, I'd say besides being this band's deepest album I'd say it's the deepest album I can think of right now off the top of my head. By deep, I mean there are 28 songs, mostly all of which are very strong tracks, and standout tracks in their own respective ways. I'll try to say something insightful about each track... <br /> <br />Note that I think theres a lot more going on on the second Disc (Mars). I would describe the first disc as good and the second as nearly mind-blowing, and extremely solid. <br /> <br />Dani California: The Mary Jane's Last Dance parallel is uncanny. When I first heard this song on the radio before the album dropped I remember turning to a friend in the car and saying this sounds a lot like Mary Jane's Last Dance. Not sure what the deal is here. I'd say that Frusciante probably heard the Tom Petty song shortly before coming up with the riff and that it was the work of the unconcsious, IF the lyrics and drum beat werent so similar too. Not sure what else to say about this one. Its a simple almost folky song with a simple drum beat that sets its tone. I like the section in the middle where anthony and John sing in unison in real high pitch. <br /> <br />Snow: This might be the catchiest song on the album and it definately was one of the first and easiest songs to grab me. Now it sounds to me like one of the poppiest songs on the album. Sounds to me like it could have easily fit into By The Way. <br /> <br />Charlie: Strong song, not one of my faves, but I could see this one growing on me over the course of years. <br /> <br />Stadium Arcadium: Very nice, one of the darker songs on the album, sung in a sad tone. One of the cooler guitar solos on the album. They use a cool, echoey, almost western-like effect for it. Everytime I hear it I picture a western saloon for some reason (think Desperado) To me theres nothing super cool about this strack other than that solo. <br /> <br />Hump De Bump: Fun song, don't listen to this one often, nothing i absolutely love about it right now. <br /> <br />She's Only 18: This one's the standout of the first disc for me. One of the best songs on the album. Arguably the best chorus on the album. So heavy, a little slow but urgent. This guitar solo works the best of any track because the segue into the last chorus is seemless and amazing. Amazing transition there, listen for it, it makes the whole song. Also love Keidis' playful bird-sounding \\"haha\\" in the middle of the solo. <br /> <br />Slow Cheetah: Acoustic ballad, not crazy about the chorus, kind of sounds cheesy to me. I wish they would have done soemthing more with it. <br /> <br />Torure Me: Fast drum beat, decent song, nothing really stands out for me to make me love it. <br /> <br />Strip My Mind: One of the slowest paced songs on the album. Nice chorus. The song works. What cool is this is a track where the whole band sings in unison for parts of it. Kinda cool, theres a couple like that i think. Cant imagine hearing this live though. <br /> <br />Especially In Michigan: I've read reviews on here criticizing this album for it's pointless and meaningless lyrics. I completely disagree with this and love the poetry thru the whole thing but this song is probably a testamate for those reviews. Other than making a reference to the Detroit Lions and Tigers (kinda cool), the lyrics dont mean much...but they work, and to me they are just random observations about the state where Kiedis and Chad Smith grew up. As far as the song goes, to me this is another stand out of the disc. I love the chorus here. Its very interesting, distorted and sounds like there might be 2 or 3 voices chanting the distortion, but it might also just be frusciante. Who knows. Very cool. <br /> <br />Warlocks: I dont care much for this one. Theres just not enough going on with it. One thing thats cool though is theres a verse in the middle that stands out because it sounds so different (\\"Make a deal with...\\") Its very cool and sounds to me like something off of Dark Side of the Moon. <br /> <br />C'Mon Girl: Arghhhh. This songs not bad at all, nice guitar riff and a cool baseline, BUT the chorus absolutely ruinsthis one for me. It just doesnt fit the song, and I'd say it even makes the song almost intolerable. Wish they would have done something with the Chorus. <br /> <br />Wet Sand: Heres a song that really evolves and has an energy that slowly builds throughout the whole song. This is an example of one of many very creative tracks on this album that shows lots of versatility by containing sections that sound somewhat different, or extrapalate on eachother. The Chorus is amazing. Theres a point about 2/3 the way through the song right when the second chorus kicks in that is the absolute climax of this song. Theres a swooshy, space-like sound effect and then the chorus kicks in, but unlike the first chorus, this one has another sound effect thats really cool and continues throughout the entire chorus, underlying everything and changing tone all along. Its very discreet and you have to listen for it. Not sure why I love this so much but, just adds energy I think. Probably something Rubin threw in to add character. Nice ending too. <br /> <br />Hey: Not much to say about this one. Kind of a lame chorus. Good placement of this song because its successor is one of the stars of the album... <br /> <br />Desecration Smile: Ohhhh yea, this song is a total emotional rollercoaster. Its a somber, its joyous, its reflective. All around just an extemely versatile and well-composed piece. It starts out sounding like it's going to be a fluid ballad but about 20 seconds in it takes a drastic turn and the mood is set. Kiedis vocals here are like nothing we've heard from him before (sung in such high pitch) He sounds a lot like Neil Young from CSNY times. Keidis' volcals here are a major and crucial component of this song, but I'd say everything else is as important. Everyone comes to play here. Nice picking guitar work by fruciante. <br /> <br />Tell Me Baby: Another gem on the album. Totally cool track. Lots of personality, great representation of this band. Cool theme about the motives of 20-somethings that move out to LA searching for something they cant even put their finger on. Nice rapping section in the middle. Very versatile track, very nice chorus. Overall extremely solid and I hope this DOES NOT become a single because I would'nt want this to be overplayed and lose its unique quality. <br /> <br />Hard to Concentrate: I think a lot of people really like this one, and personally I dont get it at all. Probably one of the 4 or 5 tracks I might dump if I were forced to cut the album down some. Nice poem, too schmoozy though. <br /> <br />21st Century: An absolute standout for me. Keidis' vocals dominate the whole song, and Fruciante brings the A-game. Very dancable song with lots of energy. Amazing chorus, amazing basework, Chad is solid on the drums, nice guitar solo closing it out. <br /> <br />She Looks to Me: Another stand out track for me. This just works, dont know why i like it, kind of reminds me of early 90's rock. Contains maybe my favorite verse on the album (\\"down in the south seas...\\") So different than the rest of the track. Cool lyrics here too. I mean really, how much better can the album get from here??? LOTS... <br /> <br />Readymade: Ohhhhhh man, I mean they keep bringing it track after track on this disc. One of a handful of total gems on the album. Hard rocking song from the start, a serious rocker, love the backround \\"ahhhhhh\\" vocals from the rest of the band behind Keidis' voice in the chorus. <br /> <br />If: sounds like a slower phish song to me. kind of a reflective song. Cool electric sound effect underlying the entire song. I'd consider this the breather of the second disc. Some might say its a refreshing break from the insanity and strength of the songs preceding and before they close the album out with another bundle of solid brilliance, others might consider this a break in the momentum. <br /> <br />Make You Feel Better: Cool song about, well... I'll leave that one up to you. Love Keidis' periodic \\"oh yea\\" high-pitch scream here. If he didnt scream it I probably would. <br /> <br />Animal Bar: One of the most complex songs on the album. It does different things. It moves, it changes. Grew on me the most. Love the chorus (\\"rain on my...\\") and the \\"babadaba\\" in the background. Crazy twist at the end and fizzles out... <br /> <br />So Much I: Oh man, how solid can this disc possibly be??? They are still bringing it with variance and full force here. Like about 20 other songs on the album, this one has its own unique charater and sound thats nothing like the others. Srong track. <br /> <br />Storm in a Teacup: One of the gems, love the verse building up to both choruses \\"little lady love youre gonna make some\\" brilliant structure of words and just well written. This is almost beastie-boys meets RHCP. You can hear the Rubin element here. Energetic all the way through, but certain parts ooze enery, particularly when it gets real quiet before the last chorus section and to me this sounds a lot like something off Check Your Head (an album i think rubin produced; not sure of this though) Its got an extraordinary quality to it, great song. <br /> <br />We Beleive: Not sure what he deal is with this one, its definately the message of the album though. I think its the band speaking directly to the album, almost a refleection from them. I could be dead wrong. Nice santana-ish guitar effect. Cool lyrics. \\"The risk is, it worth it, The disc is, it perfect?\\" I'll let you answer that one. Very cool distortion over Keidis' words to fade the track out. <br /> <br />Turn it Again: Huge rocker, very loud, led by somewhat distorted heavy electric guitar. This one is reminiscent of GunsnRoses for me, particularly toward the end. Very heavy, very distrorted, similar sound.<br /> <br />Death of a Martian: Def a gem of the album, perfect closer, like nothing theyve ever done before. Kind of trippy sound. The song kind of trickles downward the whole time. Some of the best lyrics on the album. Very cool ending poem with some of the coolest lyrics I've ever heard in song. Keidis ends the album on a somewhat screaming \\"AWAAAAAAAAY\\" love it. Great song to listen to while you reflect on what you just heard and its sad only because the album has come to an end. Oh well, time to turn it again... <br /> <br /> <br />In closing I'd say there is definately enough here to keep someone busy for a while and the depth is amazing. Let me know if this review was helpful and/or if you guys agree with my commentary. <br /> <br />Thanks.

B0007OASII|4.0|Kamelot have continued to mature with Khan on vocals over their last few records. This addition to their armoury is a very good release and the equal of anything they've done before, adding a range of skills and maturity to their previous works.<br /><br />The album kicks off with March of Mephisto which is a great, heavy rabble rouser of a track with a rolling drum sound that sounds like the percussion was recorded in a cavern somewhere. And that's meant in a nice way in this instance.<br /><br />Track two continues barnstorming along - it's fast paced all the way and with a fully body to it with fine vocals by Khan. Things don't slow down for track 3 (The Haunting) which is full of interesting movements, mellow sections and some female vocal melodies that sound, indeed, haunted.<br /><br />The fourth track moves along brilliantly as well with excellent vocals with lots of timbre evident in Khans' still maturing voice and the whole track is steeped in dynamics.<br /><br />And that's just the first four tracks folks!<br /><br />Later tracks utilise Latin language sections, atmospheric patches that actually work and the whole record is a resounding realisation of the Kamelot manifesto.<br /><br />Production wise this is as good as you'd expect, a full bodied sound that surrounds the listener and everything about the package is well thought out right down to another excellent, evocative slice of cover art.<br /><br />The tracks unfold well and for Euro metal (yeah yeah I know they're a US band but apart from Savatage have you ever come across a US band that sounded so much like a Euro metal mob) and utlimately there is not a total reliance on double time drumming, a major drawback of much of this genre. By not falling into that trap of going for speed and therefore actually losing power - or gravitas if you will - Kamelot have played perhaps their ace card.<br /><br />Overall, with the lush production, excellent tunes and good but appropriate use of keyboards, which lightly wash over tracks like This Pain (track 7) and judicious use of string elements on tunes like Moonlight this is a fine, fine record. Highly recommended.<br /><br />Any downsides are these - firstly this record is a touch self important. It's also a touch long. The use of rather intriguing interlude tracks do break the whole thing up which is useful for the listener, but really, listening to this many tracks is perhaps asking a bit much of an audience, when they could so easily have levelled the place with a round dozen tunes.keyboards, which lightly wash over tracks like This Pain (track 7) and judicious use of string elements on tunes like Moonlight this is a fine, fine record. Highly recommended. <br /> <br />Any downsides are these - firstly this record is a touch self important. It's also a touch long. The use of rather intriguing interlude tracks do break the whole thing up which is useful for the listener, but really, listening to this many tracks is perhaps asking a bit much of an audience, when they could so easily have levelled the place with a round dozen tunes. <br /> <br />

0875428940|3.0|I had a roommate once who had the Robin Wood deck. It had been a while since I'd seen the images, but I decided to check it out, perhaps with the memory of my roommate in mind, who was a very sweet person. When looking over this deck I remembered what I'd liked, and didn't like about it.<br /><br />I like the fact that the images are lively, plus the minor arcana is fully illustrated and has a definite Pagan feel. Also, the cards have very attractive backs, a lovely green Celtic knot design. (For some reason, the backs are important to me to consider in deck selection).  However...<br /><br />One reviewer here described the artwork as something from a Jehovah's Witness tract. I really have to agree with that. The images are very perky and cartoonish for the most part. Some of the people in the cards I find to be just plain creepy...the Fool and the Chariot come to mind, although there are others.<br />Over all I find the cards to be somewhat of a turnoff.<br /><br />That being said, there are lots of folks who this deck appeals to, for its heavy Wiccan/Pagan symbolism AND the happy, happy expressions on most of the cards. (Even the High Priestess is smiling...very strange to me, but perhaps comforting to some!). I think of my old roommate when I think of these cards, who was a very upbeat, happy person, but also could be serious at times, and was by no means a fluffy Wiccan wannabe. So in no way am I *condemning* the Robin Wood Deck. It just will not appeal to everyone, myself included.<br /><br />Anyone considering this deck should try to look carefully at as many images as you can before purchasing. For me, the deck was not an immediate turnoff until I started flipping through, then the strange weirdness (to me) of it started to come through. Others, obviously have a different reaction. Which is why it's always a good idea to get as much info about a deck as possible before purchase, not just to rely on reviews such as this one. My own personal favorite \\"Pagan themed\\" deck is Tarot of the Old Path, although there are many others out there that would appeal to those looking for alternative symbolism., although there are many others out there that would appeal to those looking for alternative symbolism.

B000002J1U|4.0|Led Zeppelin comes through with another fantastic album. III is known for showing the band's mellow side. Jimmy Page really shows off his ability to play the acoustic guitar on this album. \\"Friends\\" \\"Tangerine\\" \\"That's The Way\\" \\"Bron-Y-Aur Stomp\\" all display this new sound.  <br /> <br />There is still standard rock fare on this album with the radio staple \\"Immigrant Song\\", and others such as \\"Celebration Day\\", \\"Out On The Tiles\\". \\"Gallows Pole\\" should actually be considered amongst the acoustic songs but it really doesn't fit amongst them. It's a great, and often over-looked song. Bonham's drums coupled with Plant's vocals really make this song special. <br /> <br />My strongest recommendations are: \\"Immigrant Song\\", \\"Since I've Been Loving You\\" \\"Gallows Pole\\" and \\"Bron-Y-Aur Stomp\\"  <br /> <br />Overall, I don't think this should be the first Led Zeppelin album one buys. It's not the most accessible of their works because of the mixture of hard and soft tunes. This album is probably my least favorite because of the soft fare, but I still give it 4 stars. You really can't go wrong with any Led Zeppelin album.
B000EHSVQ4|5.0|It may be that that in the future, the Director's Cut of Kingdom of Heaven will be cited as one of those pivotal films that underscored the drawbacks of producing certain screenplays within the restrictions required for theatres. Some stories are simply too rich and complex to capture as they deserve to be told within the compressed timeslot that a theatre presentation dictates. This is one of those stories. <br /> <br />Thanks to the skill of Ridley as a director and that of his entire production team and cast, the theatre cut was in itself a feast for the senses. Still it necessitated paring the finished film down to essentially just what had to be told to keep the main story unfolding, so sprawling was the historical tapestry that had been captured in this screenplay and shot during production.  <br /> <br />Anyone who sees both the theatre release and the Director's Cut will appreciate what was sacrificed and which so vibrantly brings to life the characters you barely had time to get to know in the former version. The latter's rich complexity of restored sub-plots draws you - as it was always intended to - right into Ridley's compelling storytelling of the world of 12th century France and the Crusades.  <br /> <br />However, if all you as a viewer want is a film that lets you take sides and cheer for the 'good guys', then you won't get what this story offers below all the wonderful pageantry and human drama. If there is one underlying message to this film, it is that you as the viewer need to and can go beyond the deceptive simplicity of faceless stereotyping. When you comprehend Christians and Muslims as real people as they are so brilliantly depicted in the longer version of Kingdom of Heaven, then the utter futility of war for whatever reasons is resoundingly brought home.  <br /> <br />Combined with behind the scenes commentary and features on two additional disks, the Director's Cut of Kingdom of Heaven Ridley is not merely a longer version of the theatre release but rather the version that in every way deserves to be considered the definitive telling of this epic story. <br />
B000002J03|5.0|With Led Zeppelin's second release they continue to amaze with more of the same old rock & blues mix that made them famous after their first release. While this album is strong, arguably stronger than their first album, it's still not as polished as their later efforts. If I could I'd give this album 4 1/2 stars as the current rating on Amazon provides. This is a fun album to listen to. It's accessible to a lot of listeners. It's probably Led Zeppelin's most popular release with radio hits such as \\"Whole Lotta Love\\" and \\"Heartbreaker/Living Loving Maid\\". Overshadowed here is \\"Moby Dick\\" and \\"Bring It On Home\\". They are excellent songs. My personal favorite on the album is \\"Ramble On\\". It's not even close, actually.  <br /> <br />Listed here are my favorite songs in order of preference: <br /> <br />\\"Ramble On\\" <br />\\"Whole Lotta Love\\" <br />\\"Bring It On Home\\" <br />\\"Moby Dick\\" <br />\\"What Is And What Should Never Be\\" <br />\\"Heartbreaker\\" <br />\\"Living Loving Maid\\" <br />\\"Lemon Song\\" <br />\\"Thank You\\" <br /> <br />If having never purchased a Led Zeppelin album before, I would start with this one. B00005JP4U|3.0|Are movies or documentaries designed to inform or entertain? That's pretty much been a basic question most people have asked. I bring it up again because in cinematic terms Davis Guggenheim's \\"An Inconvenient Truth\\" lacks but the message Al Gore brings to the table is essential.<br /><br /> For those who don't know \\"An Inconveinet Truth\\" is a documentary which follows former vice-president Al Gore, who has been giving lectures literally across the world on the subject of global warming.<br /><br /> Guggenheim takes Gore's lecture material and cross-cuts it with other footage of Gore and stats and pie charts. Perhaps I'm not doing a great job visually describing the movie to you. Or maybe it just doesn't sound all at that interesting. That, ultimately, isn't the point. Don't walk into \\"An Inconvenient Truth\\" and expect to be thoroughly entertained. That's not to say the documentary is boring. I never onced check my watch. I listened attentively to what Gore was saying. But Gore's main intention with this documentary is simply to inform and make people act after seeing this.<br /><br /> I consider myself somewhat political. I've been interested in politics for about the last 4, 5 years. But I never knew until recently that the weather is a political issue. I knew Democrats and Republicans debate everything under the sun; tax cuts, health care, minium wage (although I don't know why!). But the weather? Who knew there was a Democrat response and a Republican response. I always thought it was a scientific fact global warming exist. I didn't know as some Republicans say \\"the jury is still out\\". But, what do I know I'm just a stupid 23 year old college student.<br /><br /> \\"An Inconvenient Truth\\" will be turned into a political documentary. But it shouldn't be. Gore isn't really blaming anyone for this problem. Yes, I admit, there are a few jabs taken at the Bush administration, but it's mostly done for laughs. Gore says it is up to all of us to help solve the problem. But, knowing what I know now, about the weather being a political issue, I understand this will be turned into a political documentary. And I also understand that a large amount of Republicans will not see this movie. Even though I'm young, I've learned something very important about people. Ideology will always trump facts. Have hurricanes been getting stronger? Have 10 of the 14 hottest summers been in recent years? Have glaciers started to melt? Have there been stories of polar bears drowning? The answer to all these question is yes. But, ideology trumps facts. If you simply don't want to believe in global warming all the facts in the world can be presented to you and it's not going to change your mind. This is sad because in the end the only people who are going to see this documentary are people who already believe in global warming. Gore's message will not reach anyone new.<br /><br /> In the end \\"An Inconvenient Truth\\" is not a rabble rousing documentary the way \\"Fahrenheit 9/11\\" was. It lacks a certain excitement I admit. But people should see this because the message is so important. This issue will affect everyone. It doesn't matter how you vote. It everyone's problem. So inform yourself and go see it! *** 1\2 out of *****<br /><br />Bottom-line: Admittedly not as exciting as \\"Fahrenheit 9/11\\" but this isn't a political documentary and it's message is more important, because it goes across party lines. Lacks a certain excitement but truly needs to be seen by everyone.ut the weather being a political issue, I understand this will be turned into a political documentary. And I also understand that a large amount of Republicans will not see this movie. Even though I'm young, I've learned something very important about people. Ideology will always trump facts. Have hurricanes been getting stronger? Have 10 of the 14 hottest summers been in recent years? Have glaciers started to melt? Have there been stories of polar bears drowning? The answer to all these question is yes. But, ideology trumps facts. If you simply don't want to believe in global warming all the facts in the world can be presented to you and it's not going to change your mind. This is sad because in the end the only people who are going to see this documentary are people who already believe in global warming. Gore's message will not reach anyone new.     In the end \\"An Inconvenient Truth\\" is not a rabble rousing documentary the way \\"Fahrenheit 9/11\\" was. It lacks a certain excitement I admit. But people should see this because the message is so important. This issue will affect everyone. It doesn't matter how you vote. It everyone's problem. So inform yourself and go see it! *** 1\2 out of *****    Bottom-line: Admittedly not as exciting as \\"Fahrenheit 9/11\\" but this isn't a political documentary and it's message is more important, because it goes across party lines. Lacks a certain excitement but truly needs to be seen by everyone.
B000065U1N|5.0|Black Hawk is quite simply the best war movie I have seen. It's an astonishing achievement that puts you right in the middle of the hellish horror faced by U.S. soldiers in Somalia in 1993. Every explosion startled me and filled me fear, every gunshot felt like it was whizzing right by me, every mistake or unforeseen event had me on the edge of my seat with stress and anger. I felt as though I had been transported to Mogadishu for 2.5 hours and plopped in the middle of the ambush faced by the 100 or so U.S. Rangers and Delta Force Troops as they set about to capture a Somalian warlord responsible for stealing Red Cross food shipments in his starvation-ravaged country. I really felt this movie, it was tangible to me; the confusion, the fear, the sense of dislocation and horror the soldiers must have faced. At the end I was emotionally and mentally drained.<br /><br />For whatever reason, I don't remember hearing much about the civil war in Somalia or about the Battle of Mogadishu on which Black Hawk Down is based. The plan seemed simple enough: the Army is sent into Somalia by the government to try to put an end to the Civil War. On October 3, 1993, a group of them were sent on a quick mission to capture the Somali warlord that had been running the country with an iron fist. It didn't take long for the operation to go completely FUBAR as two Black Hawk helicopters were shot down. Things went from bad to worse, as the Rangers found themselves surrounded by thousands of armed Somalis, whose only goal was to shoot any American soldier that invaded their space. After \\"stirring up the hornet's nest\\", the mission becomes a desperate attempt to maintain the Rangers motto, \\"Leave No Man Behind\\".<br /><br />Ridley Scott has made the ultimate war movie with Black Hawk Down. Unlike some war films that temper the battle with slower character-building sequences, you have to wait only thirty minutes for the Rangers' mission to go into effect. And the action doesn't stop for the next two hours, as the rest of the movie is filled with flying bullets, explosions and bloodshed. The fighting is so chaotic that it is hard to follow the action and tell what is happening, at times, and it becomes almost too easy to become desensitized to the violence.<br /><br />Black Hawk Down is without peer. It tells the story of 24 hours in the life of US soldiers in a clear, focused, and honorable manner. What other true-events film has come close? Apollo 13 dramatized and created people and events for a terrific film. Glory and Schindler's List did the same, successfully and honorably taking liberties with actual occurences for the sake of movie-dom. PS: check out Mike Durant's new book \\"In The Company of Heroes\\".rs, as the rest of the movie is filled with flying bullets, explosions and bloodshed. The fighting is so chaotic that it is hard to follow the action and tell what is happening, at times, and it becomes almost too easy to become desensitized to the violence.  <br />Black Hawk Down is without peer. It tells the story of 24 hours in the life of US soldiers in a clear, focused, and honorable manner. What other true-events film has come close? Apollo 13 dramatized and created people and events for a terrific film. Glory and Schindler's List did the same, successfully and honorably taking liberties with actual occurences for the sake of movie-dom. PS: check out Mike Durant's new book \\"In The Company of Heroes\\".

076790592X|4.0|My grandfather said, \\"We come into the world with fists clenched, as if holding tightly - we leave the world with palms open, willingly or unwillingly having let go of everything\\".<br /><br />Wisdom and grace in living is in willingly letting go, or in the words of Morrie Schwartz, about whom this book is written, \\"Once you learn how to die, you learn how to live\\".<br /><br />Morrie has been diagnosed with ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease), and knows that he will progressively lose all physical capability, and then will lose his life. Yet he is serene, he views his remaining time as a gift, and he makes use of it to confer a blessing on those around him.<br /><br />One of the many who is blessed is Mitch Albom, the author, a former student of Morrie's (he had been a renowned sociology professor at Brandeis). This is the story of their dialogue over the course of fourteen Tuesday visits to the home of the dying sage.<br /><br />Albom, who is on a fast career track, comes to reevaluate the significance of his priorities as a result of these interactions. He describes the sessions with his mentor lovingly, and with a deep sensitivity that goes straight to the heart.<br /><br />He also describes the news of the outside world that is unfolding as he sits at the feet of his suffering teacher. Juxtaposed against the heroic posture of the dying man, current events are shown to be positively surreal. For instance, \\"In rural Kentucky, three men threw pieces of a tombstone off a bridge, smashing the windshield of a passing car, killing a teenage girl who was traveling with her family on a religious pilgrimage. In California, the O. J. Simpson trial was heading to a conclusion, and the whole country seemed to be obsessed\\".<br /><br />And Morrie speaks, \\"Love is when you are as concerned about someone else's situation as you are about your own\\".<br /><br />Tears come easily during the reading of this very good book.<br /><br />All this having been said, why a recommendation of fours stars rather than five? Albom's writing style seems at times overly slick and a bit commercial. This is the one aspect of which Morrie would not have approved.rly slick and a bit commercial. This is the one aspect of which Morrie would not have approved.

B00004THAY|5.0|For some reason, I waited a few years to get this. Do NOT ask me why. This is a stellar album from two absolute masters. Both are absolutely playing their butts off here with gorgeous tone,especially B.B. and Lucille( does blues guitar tone get any better than that?). And both men have never sounded finer vocally(Clapton especially. Everybody knows what he can do with a Strat, but he is absolutely underrated as a vocalist).There's not a bad track on here, but real standouts are the absolutely KILLER title track, B.B.'s classics 3 O'Clock Blues, Days of Old and Help the Poor, and the beyond-cool cover of the Sam and Dave classic, Hold On I'm Coming. B.B. and Slowhand had wanted for years to do an album together, but for decades were unable to. This proves beyond a shadow of a doubt that the best things in life are worth waiting for. B.B. has never to my knowledge failed to turn in a great performance on anything, but this is the best Eric has sounded in years. Clapton has a tendency to drift into adult contemporary waters, and sometimes sounds like he's phoning it in in recent years, but put him on stage or in the studio with someone he respects and admires, and he never fails to show that he's still got the passion and the fire. Stuff like this is why myself  and many other guitar players picked up the axe in the first place. If you're a blues guitar fanatic, you NEED this. Better yet, buy a copy of this and give it to the 14 year old budding guitar player in your life. They might not appreciate it now, but in time, they will.

One of my favorites. \\"You'd better swallow your pride or you're gonna choke on it.\\" - 9/10    Bab's Uvula Who?- simple bass line, simple in everything, but still good. \\"I've got a knack for [...] everything up.\\" 7/10    86- A very basic song, very repitive to the point of annoyance. A slower song than the rest. \\"So stand aside and let the next one pass.\\" The chorus, \\"There's no return from 86,\\" can get annoying, though. 6/10    Panic Song- An instrumental for the first roughly 2 minutes, then BJ starts singing. Clever, and the intrumental doesn't bore you. It sounds panicked and leads well into the lyrics. \\"Well, the world is a sick machine, breeding a mass of [...].\\" 10/10     Stuart and the Ave. - I have heard every Green Day album there is, including the awful AI, but this song remains my favorite. Clever, awesome work with the bass and guitar, and simply a great song. \\"Seasons change as well as minds, and I'm a two-faced clown.\\" It really should have been International Superhits! They curse alot, but who cares? If you don't want cursing, you shouldn't be listening to Green Day. - 20/10    Brain Stew- way overrated. It's really not that good. Pretty boring, actually. But if you want to learn how to play bass, this is a good song to use. The bass line's pitifully easy. -6/10    Jaded- The fastest song on the album. Amazing work. Really great. \\"Hooray we're gonna die!\\" A sarcastic song. - 9/10    Westbound Sign- Probbaly, beside Brain Stew, the softest song on the album.Pretty good, doesn't bore you, intresting lyrics about Adrienne coming to California to live with Billie-Joe. \\"Weighed out her choices on a scale, prevailing nothing makes sense.\\" 8/10 [...]    Tight Wad Hill- A pretty sweet song. Not awesome, and really fast, but that's good. \\"Making the rounds once again.\\" It's a pretty good song. 9/10    Walking Contradiction- AWESOME! Clever lyrics, awesome bass line. \\"Talk is cheap, but lies are expensive.\\" The msuic video's great too. This song really deserved to get on International Superhits! - 10/10     Insomniac is a great album. But for all you losers who haven't heard anything but American Idiot and want this album to be like it, fat chance! This is a real punk album, not pop-punk. So, if you listen to pop, don't get this. If you're a real punk, get it. You'll love it, trust me.
0920668372|1.0|I don't know exactly what the problem is with this book- ordinarily when a book is a parable I can appreciate it for its message. And I realize lots of people seem to like it because unfortunately I received 4 copies as gifts (leaving me to wonder ungraciously if my loved ones actually read beyond the title before purchasing?!) It starts out great and funny and each page turn it gets a little worse until by the end I'm wondering why I feel not sentimental and touched but weirded out and miserable.  I think it is the overwhelming sadness caused by pondering the fact that my son and I will ultimately be separated, and particularly the grief that this will cause him.  But when you are bouncing your beautiful preschooler on your lap, who needs to dwell on death and separation?!  I say read \\"I Love you Stinky Face\\" by Lisa Mccourt to your kiddo instead, and enjoy celebrating a mother's undconditional love in a completely fun, well illustrated way that doesn't leave you wondering about the state of your mental health and doesn't cause your child to ask a lot of disturbing questions at much too young an age.  BTW, I love the suggestion to omit the text and use the pictures to point out the funny no no's in the book.  Maybe I will unearth it from the bottom of the book pile for that purpose!

B00000JQFM|5.0|Steve Vai says that Satriani is the one guitarist who can make his hair stand on end. This is the best example of why he says this. Just listen to the title track \\"Surfing with the Alien\\": rock-solid grove, uncanny tapping passages, middle estern modal ideas, it just does NOT quit. Looking back on this recording I can only lament that the musical concept that Satch is working with (his band, his sound, the compositions) just never got much better than this. Perhpas that is noramal, \\"first (nearly so) album syndrome\\". There are not many people who can play rock (shred) guitar better than this.
