0553565915|5.0|I had an NDE (near death experience, in my case, being near someone else's death!) in 1980 which resulted in an experience of the \\"Light\\" that was so instructive and revelatory that I read Ms. Eadie's book with great anticipation.  It, along with Betty Malz's \\"My Glimpse of Eternity\\" and Dannion Brinkley's \\"Saved by the Light\\" describe the Light I saw and know.<br /><br />My heart leapt when I read these (and other) passages from \\"Embraced by the Light\\":<br /><br />\\"I saw a pinpoint of light...I was instinctively attracted to it...  As I approached it, I noticed the figure of a man standing in it, with the light radiating all around him...the light became brilliant...I knew that no earthly eyes in their natural state could look upon this light without being destroyed.  Only spiritual eyes could endure it--and appreciate it...<br /><br />\\"I saw that the light immediately around him was golden, as if his whole body had a golden halo around it, and I could see that the golden halo burst out from around him and spread into a brilliant, magnificent whiteness that extended for some distance.  I felt his light blending into mine, literally, and I felt my light being drawn to his.  It was as if there were two lamps in a room, both shining, their light merging together.  It's hard to tell where one light ends and the other begins; they just become one light....And as our lights merged, I felt as if I had stepped into his countenance, and I felt an utter explosion of love...<br /><br />\\"Then questions began coming to my mind...His light now began to fill my mind, and my questions were answered even before I fully asked them.  His light was knowledge.  It had power to fill me with all truth.  As I gained confidence and let the light flow into me, my questions came faster than I thought possible, and they were just as quickly answered...<br /><br />\\"As more questions bubbled out of me, I became aware of his sense of humor.  Almost laughing, he suggested that I slow down, that I could know all I desired.  But I wanted to know EVERYTHING, from beginning to end.  My curiosity had always been a torment to my parents and husband -- and sometimes to me -- but now it was a blessing, and I was thrilled with the freedom of learning.  I was being taught by the master teacher!  My comprehension was such that I could understand volumes in an instant...Knowledge permeated me.  In a sense it BECAME me, and I was amazed at my ability to comprehend the mysteries of the universe simply by reflecting on them.\\"<br /><br />Compare my experience, though hers was much, much greater:<br /><br />April of 1980: Mrs. Schumeister and the Light Dream<br /><br />My \\"Light Dream\\" occurred in April of 1980 in St. Paul, MN. I was 25 years old and was engaged to my husband Jim.<br /><br />Preamble to dream/vision: In the Spring of 1980 (this is \\"real life\\", not the dream/vision yet), I was working as a station secretary at United & Children's Hospital in St. Paul, Minnesota, helping Jim through school. At the hospital, being in charge of the rolladex, one thing I did know about each patient was their religion.<br /><br />In April of 1980, a Jewish woman, 84-year-old Mrs. Ruth Schumeister, died, separated from me by only a wall. Her room was the first in the row of rooms and was therefore closest to me at my desk. Three nights later I had this dream:<br /><br />THE LIGHT DREAM<br /><br />Mrs. Schumeister has died. Jim and I are at the funeral home, in front of Mrs. Schumeister's daughter. I am filled, consumed by, a fervent desire that she accept us, even though we aren't Jewish. With every fiber of my being I yearn for this acceptance, and fear that it may be withheld. Mrs. Schumeister's daughter asks us, \\"Would you like to review the body?\\" Before I can answer, Jim, standing just behind me, grabs my left elbow and hisses, \\"You know how much I am affected by Death!\\" I think, \\"No I don't...And that hurts!\\"<br /><br />Then I hear a voice say, not in \\"out-loud\\" words, but in precisely these words, \\"Something about the nature of Death will be revealed to you.\\"<br /><br />In the next scene, Jim and I are alone in a waiting room, on the opposite sides of an oval table, kitty corner. I'm to the right, and Jim is across the table to my left. We are waiting to review the body. An empty ritual, a boring, meaningless act. Familiar, useless, custom. People do it, so now we will do it. I am very, very bored, but not unhappy. In retrospect I see that it was the familiar, deep boredom to which we, unbeknownst to ourselves, are quite accustomed. I was so bored that (amazingly enough) I had forgotten anything that was out-of-the-ordinary in the scene before: Jim's grip on my arm, his words, the Voice.<br /><br />Looking about, I cast my eyes about the room. Hither and thither.  Unexpectedly my eyes meet Jim's -- Mr. \\"You Know How Much I Am Affected By Death\\" Jim. The instant our eyes meet, to my amazement (I only knew how bored I'd been by how unbored I was then!) a joyous golden light poured out of his eyes, swept past me to the right, glittering with glitters and sparkles, swirling, dancing joyously...It wasn't as if it were one thing, but as if it were many things, friends, happy together and celebrating! Above all, celebrating! Its very \\"Being\\" was communicatory: in pure fun, anticipation and joy it radiated - I saw it was - Jim's \\"Foreknowledge of the Splendor After Death.\\" Those were the exact words of what it was, which it communicated by simply joyously being it. I know this is hard to believe.<br /><br />Following its trajectory, I turned to the right.  Before me I saw an arched doorway. Mrs. Schumeister's body lay just beyond (reclined, head higher than the feet, not supported by anything, and although I'm not sure about this part, it was as if wrapped in a kind of cocoon - I saw that death, to my surprise, was not \\"gone forever\\", but instead, a deepest of sleep). Above her body, a Light was working on her, working and pulling, working to change her into what it was.<br /><br />I couldn't see this Light clearly enough! I struggled to see it more clearly (peering as if around a bunch of heads in my way) but it was no use. I couldn't see it clearly enough. I re... what's the word? When you make due with something because you have no choice, so you console yourself with the status quo?<br /><br />Then, when I'd resolved to accept that's all I could see, suddenly the Light was in front of me, to my right, 6 or 10 feet away! It was about 6 or 8 feet tall, white and oval shaped (the smaller part of the oval shape was on the ground with the wider part above). I was instantly filled with joy, the most I'd ever felt! thinking: \\"Now, I'm finally going to be able to know everything I've always wanted to know!\\"<br /><br />My curiosity pierced into the Light and all I saw was Light. It was a golden, teaching light, that poured past me, through me (especially through my eyes), and as it did so, it taught without words. It was like reading the best book, having the best conversation, learning every second more of what one wants to know.<br /><br />Suddenly the Light did an unexpected fuzzy dissolve. During this dissolve, its power of teaching halted, as if held in abeyance. I watched, uncomprehending. After a couple of seconds, the fuzziness broke, and a GREATER power of this same Light resumed its \\"pouring past and through and into\\", it's teaching. I thought, \\"Wow! What was before was enough, and there's even more!?! This is incredible!\\" Then I became caught up again in its teaching... (I can't put it into words because it taught without words).<br /><br />Another dissolve happened and took me by surprise. I was so absorbed, I'd forgotten it had this tendency. An augmentation in the Light again!  And again I became engrossed...<br /><br />When the NEXT dissolve merely began to begin, I sensed the Power behind it and instantly knew I couldn't handle it. Its incipience contained the very beginning of the HINTS of what it contained, a world, a gift, so glorious, so revelatory I knew I could not take it in in my present form. I felt it was going to blow me into a million bits. I didn't know who or where I'd be, if I could come back, if I'd be alone... I was utterly afraid.<br /><br />I turned my head quickly to look away, to stay in this world -- to forestall this shattering. To my shock, I saw that the power of the Light had my eyes in its hold. My head could not turn away! I knew I had only a second to steel myself.  Eyes glued to the dissolve and growing Light, in greatest fear, I made my body stiff...<br /><br />At that moment, a Wind came out of the Light and blew my head to the side!<br /><br />Whew! I have never been so relieved. The Light was still to my right and communicated (I felt its humor): \\"I'm still here. Nothing prevents you from turning your head and looking again. Then you can `finally get to know everything you always wanted to know!' \\" (Being created in God's image, did I see where our gift of sarcasm comes from?)<br /><br />I thought, \\"No, thank you!\\"  Grateful for what I had seen, and what I had not seen!<br /><br />END OF LIGHT DREAM<br /><br />* * *<br /><br />By the Light's hold on my eyes, and by the wind's subsequent rescue of me, the Light taught me that I had taken it for a mere 'vehicle' - alive, yes, but alive for my personal use and enlightenment - whereas it IS (to put it mildly) alive in its own right.  How do we get to it again?  Prayer?  Yuck!  After considering it a second, we wave it away, for fear of prayer's horrible boredom.  Then I remember the dichotomy (above) between my utter boredom and its opposite!  In this regard, I love Betty Eadie's vision of prayers themselves, as they appear coming into Heaven!  And how they are attended to.<br /><br />Betty Eadie, Betty Malz, and Dannion Brinkley's experiences involved a life review, and what they learned makes their books worth owning and cherishing.  Also, what they SAW in the beyond.<br />The ending of Leif Enger's \\"Peace Like a River\\" also contains an  amazing, living description of Heaven -- tho it is fiction, it has the greatest ring of truth.<br /><br />I loved that I saw a Jewish woman (at whose death I had been present in real life) being changed by the Light into what it is.  I saw this pulling, this working on, this changing by the Light.  From death into life.round a bunch of heads in my way) but it was no use. I couldn't see it clearly enough. I re... what's the word? When you make due with something because you have no choice, so you console yourself with the status quo?    Then, when I'd resolved to accept that's all I could see, suddenly the Light was in front of me, to my right, 6 or 10 feet away! It was about 6 or 8 feet tall, white and oval shaped (the smaller part of the oval shape was on the ground with the wider part above). I was instantly filled with joy, the most I'd ever felt! thinking: \\"Now, I'm finally going to be able to know everything I've always wanted to know!\\"     My curiosity pierced into the Light and all I saw was Light. It was a golden, teaching light, that poured past me, through me (especially through my eyes), and as it did so, it taught without words. It was like reading the best book, having the best conversation, learning every second more of what one wants to know.     Suddenly the Light did an unexpected fuzzy dissolve. During this dissolve, its power of teaching halted, as if held in abeyance. I watched, uncomprehending. After a couple of seconds, the fuzziness broke, and a GREATER power of this same Light resumed its \\"pouring past and through and into\\", it's teaching. I thought, \\"Wow! What was before was enough, and there's even more!?! This is incredible!\\" Then I became caught up again in its teaching... (I can't put it into words because it taught without words).    Another dissolve happened and took me by surprise. I was so absorbed, I'd forgotten it had this tendency. An augmentation in the Light again!  And again I became engrossed...    When the NEXT dissolve merely began to begin, I sensed the Power behind it and instantly knew I couldn't handle it. Its incipience contained the very beginning of the HINTS of what it contained, a world, a gift, so glorious, so revelatory I knew I could not take it in in my present form. I felt it was going to blow me into a million bits. I didn'tknow who or where I'd be, if I could come back, if I'd be alone... I was utterly afraid.    I turned my head quickly to look away, to stay in this world -- to forestall this shattering. To my shock, I saw that the power of the Light had my eyes in its hold. My head could not turn away! I knew I had only a second to steel myself.  Eyes glued to the dissolve and growing Light, in greatest fear, I made my body stiff...    At that moment, a Wind came out of the Light and blew my head to the side!    Whew! I have never been so relieved. The Light was still to my right and communicated (I felt its humor): \\"I'm still here. Nothing prevents you from turning your head and looking again. Then you can `finally get to know everything you always wanted to know!' \\" (Being created in God's image, did I see where our gift of sarcasm comes from?)    I thought, \\"No, thank you!\\"  Grateful for what I had seen, and what I had not seen!      END OF LIGHT DREAM    * * *    By the Light's hold on my eyes, and by the wind's subsequent rescue of me, the Light taught me that I had taken it for a mere 'vehicle' - alive, yes, but alive for my personal use and enlightenment - whereas it IS (to put it mildly) alive in its own right.  How do we get to it again?  Prayer?  Yuck!  After considering it a second, we wave it away, for fear of prayer's horrible boredom.  Then I remember the dichotomy (above) between my utter boredom and its opposite!  In this regard, I love Betty Eadie's vision of prayers themselves, as they appear coming into Heaven!  And how they are attended to.    Betty Eadie, Betty Malz, and Dannion Brinkley's experiences involved a life review, and what they learned makes their books worth owning and cherishing.  Also, what they SAW in the beyond.       The ending of Leif Enger's \\"Peace Like a River\\" also contains an   amazing, living description of Heaven -- tho it is fiction, it has the greatest ring of truth.    I loved that I saw a Jewish woman (at whose death I had been present in real life) being changed by the Light into what it is.  I saw this pulling, this working on, this changing by the Light.  From death into life.
B0006M4SO6|5.0|This is the recording Pat Metheny has been building towards his whole career. NOW I understand what Pat was aiming at all these years. He's been trying to pull off a true fusion of world music, folk, bebop, and minimalism. That requires incredible chops, composing ability, and taste. Pat's chops have been good enough to play virtually anything he wanted at least since 1989's Question and Answer. He's been writing strong tunes at least since his 1991 collaboration with John Scofield, I Can See Your House From Here. But the compositions on past Pat Metheny Group recordings have uniformly been marred by an excess of sentimentalism and a lack of taste, especially in the vocal arrangements. The ability to write a compelling suite of compositions was really the last barrier Pat faced. And boy has he overcome it! The Way Up is really 69 minutes of through-composed music with room built in for soloing. It is both intellectually rigorous and incredibly moving. Up until now, I've begrudged Pat's incredible financial success with his main group because there have been so many other bands that have left him in the dust artistically but haven't been supported by the public. But it's time to eat crow. The Way Up is nothing less than transcendent. If you would like to read more reviews like this, check out JazzboNotes.com.
B000056VJ7|1.0|It is sad, and more than a little scary, to see how many reviews use the word \\"classic\\" to describe this roadkill of an album. To do so further reduces the word to utterly uselessness. <br /> <br />\\"Bat Out of Hell\\" remains what is was in 1978 -- a horrifically bad set of songs made all the worse by the bombastic and pompous production. That people still listen to this today just goes to show that no one has even gone broke underestimating the taste of the American public. If you have not had a copy of this for the past 28 years you need to think long and hard: If you have gone so long without it, why buy it now? <br /> <br />Overwrought and completely and utterly unlistenable, it is claptrap like this that remind us just what it was that punk was (thankfully) rebelling against in the first place. <br /> <br />Avoid.  For all that is good and holy in this world, AVOID!

B000E97HIA|5.0|I can't even fix my lips to say I've been a Prince fan. I was never too sure what he was about. Yeah, I was there for \\"I Wanna Be Your Lover\\" in the late '70s. I took mental notes as he dropped hits tit-for-tat against big-dog MJ throughout the '80s. I even caught the rocky '90s, where Prince battled his label and fought for continued relevance simultaneously. I admittedly own a couple of old Prince albums, but I was just trying to get girls, man. I've heard Prince enough to know what he's capable of, but it's just now, with the release of 3121, that I'm starting to listen.  <br /> <br />With the warbled intro-title track, I thought, \\"Uh oh, what would this say if it was played backwards?\\", but what followed was nothing but high-quality Prince. The Purple One pulls no punches with the freak-funk \\"Black Sweat\\", which features Prince's classic falsetto that should all but put Pharrell out of business and flashes a sound that the strip clubs will fiend for, yet actually conveys a message of dance and discipline. \\"Lolita\\" is a definite jump-back to his '80s style with dance-worthy synth chords and playful call-and-response reminiscent of himself and The Time. \\"Beautiful, Loved and Blessed\\" featuring Tamar has a sound you would swear was neo-soul, but is straight gospel in terms of its message. Only for the Saved & Sexy!!! \\"Get On The Boat\\" is a metaphor of positivity wrapped into a '70s style funk session. Envision the cut \\"Musicology\\" with a big band behind it, you're in the ballpark. It's almost like Prince knew I was an EWF fan! I play this one back often and it's the longest cut here! <br /> <br />Prince's conversion to Jehovah's Witness is no secret, but just in case anyone out there is wondering, \\"What about his infamous sex songs?\\" well...just don't call them that anymore. But there are plenty of intimate (yet somehow clean) joints in this package, such as the fluid & steamy \\"Incense and Candles\\" (\\"I know you want to take off all your clothes/But please don't doit\\"), the emotionally combative \\"The Dance\\", the bluesy \\"Satisfied\\" and the salsa-inducing \\"Te Amo Corazon\\". Those that are not standing over every word will not realize the strategically air-brushed lyrics. <br /> <br />This album is simply a thoroughly diverse work of art that eerily manages to sing a moral and even Christian message without sacrificing the magical mystique Prince has forged over the years. A feat that thousands of artists have attempted and failed. Don't get me wrong, this is not a gospel album, but it's a refreshingly positive change to the Prince of old, at least lyrically. And to be this sharp pushing 50 is just short of unheard of. He hasn't lost a thing, folks. He's just managed to get the \\"new him\\" 100% right this time around, and I wouldn't be surprised if 3121 leads others to the path of righteousness. Finally, an album with a purpose!
B00009W0U4|3.0|This movie is among the 1000 Best Movies in DVD by Peter Travers, that is why I bought it. During 10 minutes, you see the beautiful Belucci being raped on a tunnel in Paris, and that scene is disturbing. The whole movie is, with an interesting plot told backwards, from the end to the beginning on a full day of the life of these characters. At the beginning of the movie (which would be the end of the story), we are at the club \\"Rectum\\" (ass in Latin ...), a gay night club where people meet to have sex. There, Marcus is looking for Tenia, the responsible for raping and beating Alex, his girlfriend. Another extremely disturbing scene takes place in that club (but I am not to say, since I don't want to spoil the movie), and so on ... Saying this is not a good movie would not be fair, but it is definetely a movie not to please the majority of the public, with a kind of \\"dizzy\\" camera style, moving here and there, in circles, crazy, to tell a crazy-disturbing story. It's a French movie, so don't expect anything related to American standards, because European films are different from American. The movie won best film at the Stockholm Film Festival (2002), and was in the official selection of the Sundance Film Festival (2003) and Cannes (2002) among others. The DVD comes with an interesting documentary about the special effects, and two lame \\"deleted scenes\\" that look more like video clips than deleted scenes. The movie is in French with Spanish and English subtitles.<br /><br />After all, an interesting movie which will please those who like to see the beautiful Bellucci, gay and lesbian movies, violence, disturbing scenes, weird stories, and transgression on art.

B0001HAISG|5.0|This movie has the most amazing look to it...like an animated Maxfield Parrish painting.  Neverland is full of lush, dense color, and peopled by all sorts of fantastical creatures, from the ever popular Tinkerbell to the beautiful, but feral mermaids.  The story stays pretty true to Barrie's original, with the emphasis on Wendy and a girl's sometimes frightening journey into womanhood.  And because of that emphasis, the tradition of having the same actor play Mr. Darling and Captain Hook has more resonance than ever.   <br /> <br />And what an actor.  Jason Isaacs is so good in each part that a viewer could mistake him for two different actors.  His Mr. Darling is a rather pathetically timid man, redeemed only by his obvious love for his wife and children.  His Captain Hook, on the other hand, encapsulates everything about adult males that gives Wendy pause as she contemplates growing up.  He's angry, vengeful, violent, even lustful.  But he's also attractive (Hook has amazing costumes and wigs, which provide a frame for Jason's wonderfully expressive eyes) and seductive and worldly, which gives him an appeal, even as he frightens her so badly. <br /> <br />It's really a great performance, because, through it, you can see that Hook is a mirror-image of Peter Pan. A funhouse mirror, but a mirror, nonetheless. Peter refuses to grow up and move on, and Hook refuses to let go of his grudge and move on. Peter doesn't respect adults, and Hook resents youth. Both are attracted to Wendy, because she exudes her own kind of power...the power to make a young man yearn to be better and an older man yearn to be young. They are locked in a combat that they simply refuse to relinquish, because they're both consumed by their lust for the fight. <br /> <br />All the performances in the movie range between very good and excellent.  Rachel Hurd-Wood is particularly charming and winsome as Wendy, and the Lost Boys are cute and funny.  Ludivine Sagnier is a very pretty, but also a veryarch and malevolent Tinkerbell.  The only occasional weak link is Jeremy Sumpter as Peter Pan.  He has a great look for the role and the youthful exuberance to make a convincing Pan, but his line delivery sometimes slips from cocky into smarmy, and it makes him a slightly less attractive figure. <br /> <br />Still, there is so much good about this movie--Jason, Rachel, the magnificent setpieces, and the attention to even the smallest detail, not to mention the classic story--that I gave it 5 stars.  The extras on the DVD are very nice, as well.  I recommend especially \\"Through the Eyes of Captain Hook\\", which is comprised of footage that Jason Isaacs shot on set, and the feature about the mermaids, which shows how much work went into creating a scene that lasted only a few seconds on-screen. <br />
B00005JOVN|3.0|Poseidon is not as bad as the critics say it is.  It's a decent movie, with very realistic special effects, atmospheric booming sounds of explosions and rushing water, and some impressive directing.  Two things that are bad about Poseidon, are....<br /><br />1. The bland talentless acting.<br /><br />2. And the story. (There isn't any)<br /><br />The movie starts off very quickly and goes straight into the action of the gigantic wave smashing into the titanic sized 'Poseidon', which is very impressive.  After the disaster (that kills nearly everybody) a group of survivors try to escape by making their way through the dangerous maze that is the upside down cruise ship.  And thats it.<br /><br />Characters are poor, with brief introductions it is hard to form a relationship with any of the cast.  Some characters you feel as if you don't care if they die a horrible death.  However, with Richard Dryfuss' and Kurt Russell's characters you do care if they live or die. (Maybe its because they are the only GOOD actors in this entire movie) Some deaths in the movie are very gruesome, but also funny.  With women smashing through glass, guys running around on fire and a dancefloor full of people being electrocuted by dangling power lines.  The music and the excellent audio makes every scene thrilling and exciting.  Other scenes evoke situations of panic towards the viewer.<br /><br />Overall, Poseidon is just an OK movie with minimal flaws.  Not a summer blockbusting hit, but more of a Sunday evening treat.  The director has made a brave attempt at remaking the original, but the questions are:<br /><br />Is it as good as the original?<br /><br />The answer:  .....No.<br /><br /> Is it better than Titanic?<br /><br />The answer: YES.

B000001FFJ|5.0|this is one of the coolest albums i own.  I think this is really where Waits started perfecting his stranger musical writings, but there's still plenty of room for the sligtely more normal songs of his earlier style.   <br /> <br />begining with the see shanty singapore, waits uses his idiosyncratic voice in a great way with the chanting, and the malets are awesome.  one of my favorites on the album is clap hands, which uses mallets again, but perhaps in an even cooler way than on singapore.  this song has some of the most interesting lyrics on the record, my favorite line being 'a Cincinatti jacket and a sad luck dame; hanging out the window with a bottle full of rain.' the song creates an atmosphere of the most exagerated old school urban decadence, completely grey and raw. cemetary polka sees chanting again, but somehow the style is quite different than on clap hands.   <br /> <br />to me the coolest part of the delivery of waits is his ability to use his voice to conjure so many different sounds and emotions.  this record goes from the delicacy of time to the surreal bark of cemetery polka, desperate and intense on anywhere i lay my head, and swinging and groving on walking spanish and jockey full of bourbon.  and just as his voice itself is varried, so too are the song styles, instrumentation, and overall feel the songs give off.  somehow waits is able to go from popular music to avant garde strangness so fast and so smoothly that he creates a sound totaly his own on totaly different songs.  if you told me waits had multiple personality disorder problems around the recording of this record i might believe you.     <br /> <br />as this record is in the middle of his discography i think it is one of the most essential, it just showcases so much. one thing i think people have to realize is that there wasn't a perfect point when Waits started playing very strange music, and to me that slowely happened until his albums became more consistantly in one style again.  some of the songs here are very weird, such as diamonds and gold, but others are pop songs, such as downtown train. i suppose not everyone will feel this is a good thing, this album doesn't have the emotional or concistancy, nor the pure strangness of an album like Blood Money, but it probably has better songs.  get it.

006441034X|5.0|I consider myself picky about the books I like....This one was right up my alley.  While trying to find books to fill the void while waiting for the next Harry Potter to come out, my nephew told me about Howl.  I was surprised that it was written in 1987 (which would put me in highschool) and I'd never heard of it before.  Well, I loved it.  It has a little of everything....romance, humor, mystery and lots of magic!   <br /> <br />Sophie is the oldest of 3 sisters and therefore (in her mind) doomed to a life of bad luck and boredom.  She accepts her fate as a hat maker in her family's shop until the dreaded Witch of the Waste visits her store and in a fit of temper, turns Sophie into an old woman and furthermore the curse won't allow Sophie to tell anyone what happened to her. <br /> <br />Sophie has no choice but to leave the shop and seek her fortune.  She decides to go to Wizard Howl (A handsome and powerful, but incredibly conceited wizard who lives in a castle that is fueled by a fire demon) in hopes that he can remove the spell.   <br /> <br />Howl is the most interesting character.  He is vain and selfish and just when you think you hate him, he turns kind and compassionate.  By the end of the book, you can see how Sophie falls in love with him.  They are a perfect match for each other. <br /> <br />The book can be complicated for younger readers (I even found myself re-reading particularly difficult chapters to make sure I had grasped them) I also found myself coming up with questions that don't seem to be answered in the book.  However, all in all, I thought the book was imaginitive and entertaining.  It's full of colorful characters and creative plots!
6305922756|5.0|This first \\"mockumentary\\" is a treat to watch, chronicling the (invented) adventures of the rock group Spinal Tap, \\"Britain's loudest band.\\" <br /> <br />Filled with a host of comedic talent, there's much to laugh at in this film, but one of its great strengths (and what sets it apart from the team's later mockumentaries such as Waiting for Guffman and Best in Show) is that it is never too absurd to be believed. The characters in this film are absolutely believable and the situations they get themselves in are, too (like the stage malfunctions, and the cancelled bookings). <br /> <br />This is a movie that never gets old, and it's recommended for all fans of comedy and music. Five stars.
B000ELIVB0|5.0|Wow. This is captivating stuff: like artists such as M83, the Knife's Silent Shout has a \\"future noir\\" sound that brings drama, depth and vibrancy to the stereotypically sterile elements of electronic music.   Simultaneously combining female, male, and high-pitched alien (!) layers within the same voice, the eerie pitch-shifted vocals give the melodies a slippery strangeness that is also surprisingly powerful.  \\"Marble House\\", for example, soars with a chorus that is both heartbreaking and uplifting; \\"Forest Families\\" is like the evil step-sister to Ladytron's \\"Soft Power\\";  \\"Neverland\\" thumps along on a catchy yet otherwordly beat; and \\"The Captain\\" combines atmospheric instrumentation with a haunting chirp of a vocal that will send shivers down your spine.  True, the lyrics on this album are a bit oblique and sometimes hard to decipher (\\"We had a communist in the family / I had to wear a mask\\"); but lyrics are not the point here as much as generating an emotion in the listener.  And on that level, the Knife have definitely succeeded -- I can't stop listening to this album, and I definitely can't forget its effect on me.  One of the best of the year so far.
